rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.

This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

so_18771291: Copy files from source directory to target directory and exclude specific file types from specified directories
so_19913855: Copying files while preserving directory structure
Top-3 Scripts:
so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

Explanations about Options.-e:
Exclude the test named in testname from the list of tests made to determine the file
 type. Valid test names are:
Explanations about Options.-F:
Use the specified string as the separator between the filename and the file result
 returned. Defaults to ‘:’.
Explanations about Options.-r:
Don't translate unprintable characters to \ooo. Normally file translates
 unprintable characters to their octal representation.
Explanations about Options.-c:
Cause a checking printout of the parsed form of the magic file. This is usually
 used in conjunction with the -m flag to debug a new magic file before installing it.

so_36142838: cp --parents

cat /path/to/files | xargs cp --parents -t new_directory

while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

Top-3 Scripts:
ul_518133: shopt -s dotglob failglob
find . -depth -regextype egrep -type d -regex '.*/([^/]*)/\1' -print0 |
while IFS= read -r -d '' path; do
  mv -n -t "$path/.." "$path"/* &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

find . -depth -type d | grep -E -x '.*/([^/]*)/\1' |
while IFS= read -r path; do
  mv "$path"/* "$path/.." &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

so_63818260: dest=/path/to/dir
while IFS= read -r -d '' filename # read null-delimited list from find 
do basename="${filename##*/}"
   if [[ -e "$dest/$basename" ]] 
   then ctr=0
        while [[ -e "$dest/$basename.$((++ctr))" ]]; do : ; done # find available name
        mv "$dest/$basename" "$dest/$basename.$ctr"
   fi
   cp -pv "$filename" "$dest/$basename"     
done < <( find ./ -name '*.gql' -type f -print0 ) # null-delimit

so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

so_54400775: find . -iregex ".*HeadersConstants\.java" |\
rsync -v --files-from=- ./ ${destination}/

find . -path ./destination -prune \
    -o -iregex ".*HeadersConstants\.java" -print |\
rsync -v --file-from=- ./ ./destination/

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-prune:
True; if the file is a directory, do not descend into it. If -depth is given, then
 -prune has no effect. Because -delete implies -depth, you cannot usefully use
 -prune and -delete together.
 For example, to skip the directory `src/emacs' and all files and directories
 under it, and print the names of the other files found, do something like this:
 find . -path ./src/emacs -prune -o -print

Answers.MP Summary: strip last component from file name

Explanations about Options.-c:
Create a new archive. Arguments supply the names of the files to be archived.
 Directories are archived recursively, unless the --no-recursion option is given.
Explanations about Options.-T: Get names to extract or create from FILE.
Explanations about Options.-C:
Change to DIR before performing any operations. This option is order-sensitive,
 i.e. it affects all options that follow.
Explanations about Options.-x:
Extract files from an archive. Arguments are optional. When given, they specify
 names of the archive members to be extracted.
Explanations about Options.--transform: Use sed replace EXPRESSION to transform file names.

 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

to.mpsum: as the filename. --logdir <name> Writes each synchronization log output in a new file in the specified directory. --logexpire <hours> Removes logs older than the value specified (in hours). This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory. The ownCloud Client reads a configuration file.  You can locate this configuration file as follows: On Linux distributions: $HOME/.config/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg On Microsoft Windows systems: %APPDATA%\ownCloud\owncloud.cfg On MAC OS X systems: $HOME/Library/Preferences/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg The configuration file contains settings using the Microsoft Windows .ini file format. You can overwrite changes using the ownCloud configuration dialog. NOTE: Use caution when making changes to the ownCloud Client configuration  file. Top-3 Similar Questions: su_1305704: Find and copy folders recursively but keep the structure
so_40085308: Linux - How to copy recursive from each folder N files and keep same folder structure
so_57491477: copying files to another folder using bash
Top-3 Scripts: su_1305704: find . -name .svn -type d -exec sh -c 'for arg do echo cp -R "$arg" ../bar/"$arg"; done' sh {} +

so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

ul_518133: How to move some specific folder keeping a predefined directory structure?
so_63818260: Copy files of specific type but prevent overwriting files
Top-3 Scripts:
so_36142838: while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

ul_518133: shopt -s dotglob failglob
find . -depth -regextype egrep -type d -regex '.*/([^/]*)/\1' -print0 |
while IFS= read -r -d '' path; do
  mv -n -t "$path/.." "$path"/* &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

find . -depth -type d | grep -E -x '.*/([^/]*)/\1' |
while IFS= read -r path; do
  mv "$path"/* "$path/.." &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

so_63818260: dest=/path/to/dir
while IFS= read -r -d '' filename # read null-delimited list from find 
do basename="${filename##*/}"
   if [[ -e "$dest/$basename" ]] 
   then ctr=0
        while [[ -e "$dest/$basename.$((++ctr))" ]]; do : ; done # find available name
        mv "$dest/$basename" "$dest/$basename.$ctr"
   fi
   cp -pv "$filename" "$dest/$basename"     
done < <( find ./ -name '*.gql' -type f -print0 ) # null-delimit

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_40085308: Linux - How to copy recursive from each folder N files and keep same folder structure
so_67038100: To copy Linux directory structures/tree **only** without files and preserve attributes
Top-3 Scripts:
so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_36142838: Copy files from list while keeping subdirectory structure
Top-3 Scripts:
so_36142838: cat /path/to/files | xargs cp --parents -t new_directory

while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

Top-3 Scripts:
so_67038100: find foo -type d -exec bash -c "d=\"{}\"; dnew=\$(echo \$d | sed 's/^foo/tmp/') ; mkdir -p \$dnew ; chmod --reference=\$d \$dnew ; chown --reference=\$d \$dnew ; touch --reference=\$d \$dnew " \;

> chmod --reference=olddir newdir # we copy modes rwx,
> chown --reference=olddir newdir # we copy owner,
> touch --reference=olddir newdir # we copy dates.

Explanations about Options.--reference: use RFILE's owner and group rather than specifying OWNER:GROUP values

Explanations about Options.-z:
With this option, rsync compresses the file data as it is sent to the destination
 machine, which reduces the amount of data being transmitted - something that is
 useful over a slow connection.
Explanations about Options.-a:
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.
Explanations about Options.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
Explanations about Options.--files-from:
Using this option allows you to specify the exact list of files to transfer (as
 read from the specified FILE or - for standard input). It also tweaks the default
 behavior of rsync to make transferring just the specified files and directories
 easier:
Explanations about Options.-v:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
Explanations about Options.--relative:
Use relative paths. This means that the full path names specified on the command
 line are sent to the server rather than just the last parts of the filenames. This
 is particularly useful when you want to send several different directories at the
 same time. For example, if you used this command:
Explanations about Options.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.
Explanations about Options.--include:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an include
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.
Explanations about Options.--progress:
This option tells rsync to print information showing the progress of the transfer.
 This gives a bored user something to watch. With a modern rsync this is the same
 as specifying --info=flist2,name,progress, but any user-supplied settings for those
 info flags takes precedence (e.g. "--info=flist0 --progress").

Top-3 Scripts:
ul_518133: shopt -s dotglob failglob
find . -depth -regextype egrep -type d -regex '.*/([^/]*)/\1' -print0 |
while IFS= read -r -d '' path; do
  mv -n -t "$path/.." "$path"/* &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

find . -depth -type d | grep -E -x '.*/([^/]*)/\1' |
while IFS= read -r path; do
  mv "$path"/* "$path/.." &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_63818260: Copy files of specific type but prevent overwriting files
Top-3 Scripts:
so_63818260: dest=/path/to/dir
while IFS= read -r -d '' filename # read null-delimited list from find 
do basename="${filename##*/}"
   if [[ -e "$dest/$basename" ]] 
   then ctr=0
        while [[ -e "$dest/$basename.$((++ctr))" ]]; do : ; done # find available name
        mv "$dest/$basename" "$dest/$basename.$ctr"
   fi
   cp -pv "$filename" "$dest/$basename"     
done < <( find ./ -name '*.gql' -type f -print0 ) # null-delimit

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

rsync.mpsum: a fast, versatile, remote (and local) file-copying tool
rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_518133: How to move some specific folder keeping a predefined directory structure?
ul_208229: Copying files containing specific text preserving directory structure
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_518133: find . -depth -type d | grep -E -x '.*/([^/]*)/\1' |
while IFS= read -r path; do
  mv "$path"/* "$path/.." &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

ul_208229: $ cd /path/to/srcdir
$ grep -lr PATTERN . | tar -T - -cf - | tar -C /path/to/dstdir -xf -

Explanations about Options.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
Explanations about Options.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
Explanations about Options.-x:
Select only those matches that exactly match the whole line. For a regular
 expression pattern, this is like parenthesizing the pattern and then surrounding it
 with ^ and $.

so_42038389: import io
import os

work_dir = '.'
for root, dirnames, filenames in os.walk(work_dir):
    for filename in filenames:
        path = os.path.join(root, filename)
        io.open(path, mode='w').close()

Top-3 Scripts:
so_67038100: find foo -type d -exec bash -c "d=\"{}\"; dnew=\$(echo \$d | sed 's/^foo/tmp/') ; mkdir -p \$dnew ; chmod --reference=\$d \$dnew ; chown --reference=\$d \$dnew ; touch --reference=\$d \$dnew " \;

> chmod --reference=olddir newdir # we copy modes rwx,
> chown --reference=olddir newdir # we copy owner,
> touch --reference=olddir newdir # we copy dates.

Explanations about Options.--reference: use RFILE's mode instead of MODE values

Top-3 Scripts:
su_748821: rsync -avz foo:src/bar /data/tmp

   This  would  recursively transfer all files from the directory src/bar on the machine foo into the /data/tmp/bar directory on the local machine. The files are transferred in "archive" mode, which ensures that sym‐
   bolic links, devices, attributes, permissions, ownerships, etc. are preserved in the transfer.  Additionally, compression will be used to reduce the size of data portions of the transfer.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_40085308: Linux - How to copy recursive from each folder N files and keep same folder structure
Top-3 Scripts:
so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

print the first NUM lines instead of the first 10; with the leading '-', print all

../bar

~/bar

so_40085308: #!/bin/bash

for subdir in $(find ~/foo -type d); do
  subdir_relative=$(echo $subdir | sed 's:.*foo/::g')
  mkdir "$subdir_relative"
  for file in $(find "$subdir" -type f | head -n 10); do
    cp "$file" "~/bar/$subdir_relative/"
  done
done

su_748821: rsync -avz foo:src/bar /data/tmp

   This  would  recursively transfer all files from the directory src/bar on the machine foo into the /data/tmp/bar directory on the local machine. The files are transferred in "archive" mode, which ensures that sym‐
   bolic links, devices, attributes, permissions, ownerships, etc. are preserved in the transfer.  Additionally, compression will be used to reduce the size of data portions of the transfer.

ul_518133: How to move some specific folder keeping a predefined directory structure?
so_63818260: Copy files of specific type but prevent overwriting files
Top-3 Scripts:
so_36142838: --parents                 -- append source path to target directory

cat /path/to/files | xargs cp --parents -t new_directory

/path/to/files.txt

while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)
ul_518133: rmdir: failed to remove './A/A'

so_63818260: dest=/path/to/dir
while IFS= read -r -d '' filename # read null-delimited list from find 
do basename="${filename##*/}"
   if [[ -e "$dest/$basename" ]] 
   then ctr=0
        while [[ -e "$dest/$basename.$((++ctr))" ]]; do : ; done # find available name
        mv "$dest/$basename" "$dest/$basename.$ctr"
   fi
   cp -pv "$filename" "$dest/$basename"     
done < <( find ./ -name '*.gql' -type f -print0 ) # null-delimit

Answers.MP Summary: presumably creating or updating package.json and running any other initialization-related operations. The init command is transformed to a corresponding npx operation as follows: · npm init foo -> npx create-foo · npm init @usr/foo -> npx @usr/create-foo · npm init @usr -> npx @usr/create Any  additional  options  will  be passed directly to the command, so npm init foo --hello will map to npx create-foo --hello. If the initializer is omitted (by just calling npm init), init will fall  back  to  legacy init  behavior.  It  will  ask you a bunch of questions, and then write a package.json for you. It will attempt to make reasonable guesses based on  existing  fields,  dependencies, and  options selected. It is strictly additive, so it will keep any fields and values that were already set. You can also use -y/--yes to skip the questionnaire altogether.  If  you pass --scope, it will create a scoped package. See Also · https://github.com/isaacs/init-package-json · npm help package.json · npm help version · npm help scope April 2020                                NPM-INIT(1)

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_518133: How to move some specific folder keeping a predefined directory structure?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_518133: shopt -s dotglob failglob
find . -depth -regextype egrep -type d -regex '.*/([^/]*)/\1' -print0 |
while IFS= read -r -d '' path; do
  mv -n -t "$path/.." "$path"/* &&
  rmdir "$path"
done

Explanations about Options.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
Explanations about Options.-x:
Select only those matches that exactly match the whole line. For a regular
 expression pattern, this is like parenthesizing the pattern and then surrounding it
 with ^ and $.

rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

Answers.MP Summary: presumably creating or updating package.json and running any other initialization-related operations. The init command is transformed to a corresponding npx operation as follows: · npm init foo -> npx create-foo · npm init @usr/foo -> npx @usr/create-foo · npm init @usr -> npx @usr/create Any  additional  options  will  be passed directly to the command, so npm init foo --hello will map to npx create-foo --hello. If the initializer is omitted (by just calling npm init), init will fall  back  to  legacy init  behavior.  It  will  ask you a bunch of questions, and then write a package.json for you. It will attempt to make reasonable guesses based on  existing  fields,  dependencies, and  options selected. It is strictly additive, so it will keep any fields and values that were already set. You can also use -y/--yes to skip the questionnaire altogether.  If  you pass --scope, it will create a scoped package. See Also · https://github.com/isaacs/init-package-json · npm help package.json · npm help version · npm help scope April 2020                                NPM-INIT(1)
